Q0.reasoning: The obstetrician explicitly requests fetal whole exome sequencing (WES) at 22 weeks' gestation.

Q1.reasoning: BCBS FEP WES policies do not impose a strict age cutoff that would exclude prenatal/fetal testing; the patient is a fetus at 22 weeks and no age-based exclusion is applicable or specified.

Q2.reasoning: BCBS FEP policies typically require an appropriate ordering clinician but do not universally restrict ordering to a single specialty in the documentation provided; the obstetrician (MFM/OB) ordering prenatal WES is commonly acceptable but no specific ordering-provider specialty requirement is documented here.

Q3.reasoning: Payer coverage criteria for WES include evaluation of multiple congenital anomalies/multisystem fetal anomalies to identify a genetic etiology; prenatal imaging shows multiple congenital anomalies affecting different organ systems, meeting a defined clinical indication.

Q4.reasoning: BCBS FEP typically requires prior standard testing (eg, chromosomal microarray and/or targeted chromosomal testing) before WES in the prenatal setting; the patient has no prior genetic testing documented.

Q5.reasoning: Family history is relevant under coverage considerations; a maternal aunt reported to have dysmorphic features is present and is pertinent to genetic etiologic evaluation.

Q6.reasoning: BCBS FEP WES coverage commonly requires documentation of pre-test genetic counseling for informed consent and appropriate test selection; there is no documentation of pre-test genetic counseling for this patient.

Q7.reasoning: CPT 81415 corresponds to clinical whole exome sequencing (proband/exome sequencing), which best matches the requested fetal WES.

Q8.reasoning: Although the clinical indication (multisystem fetal anomalies) supports WES, BCBS FEP coverage requires completion of prior recommended testing (eg, chromosomal microarray) and documentation of pre-test genetic counseling; those prerequisites are not met, so the test is not covered as requested.
